post_title: Why AWS, Google and Oracle are backing the Valkey Redis fork
title: Valkey Redis Fork Backed by AWS, Google, and Oracle Hosted by Linux Foundation
post_content:
The Linux Foundation has recently announced that it will host Valkey, a fork of the popular Redis in-memory data store. This open-source project is backed by some of the biggest names in the tech industry, including AWS, Google Cloud, Oracle, Ericsson, and Snap.

Redis is a widely used data store that powers many large commercial and open-source deployments. Its history is marked by a few licensing disputes, including a recent change in licensing that made it difficult to create a commercial version of the software. This led to the creation of Valkey, which is now being hosted by the Linux Foundation.

The original Redis license was permissive, allowing for multiple branches and different licensing and development ideas. However, the recent change in licensing made it incompatible with the standard definition of "open source." This change opened the door for a commercial version of the software.

The major cloud service providers, including AWS, Google Cloud, and Oracle, have all profited from the open-source version of Redis. They are now launching a fork within the Linux Foundation. This fork, called Valkey, is being backed by AWS and is designed to keep the old group of maintainers together.

AWS longtime Redis maintainer Madelyn Olson started the project in her own GitHub account. When the news broke that Redis had changed its license, many of the current Redis maintainers immediately decided to move on. The original Redis private channel included five maintainers, three from Redis, Olson, and Alibaba's Zhao Zhao, as well as a small group of committers who immediately signed on to what is now Valkey.

Redis founder Salvatore Sanfilippo had initially launched the project under the BSD license, partly because he wanted to be able to create a commercial fork at some point. However, the new license requires commercial agreements to offer Redis-as-a-service, making it difficult to create a commercial version of the software.

The current reality is that the large cloud vendors, with the notable exception of Microsoft, quickly rallied behind Valkey. This fork originated at AWS, where longtime Redis maintainer Madelyn Olson initially started the project in her own GitHub account. The maintainers from Redis unsurprisingly did not sign on, but as David Nally, AWS's director for open-source strategy and marketing, told me, the Valkey community would welcome them with open arms.

In conclusion, the creation of Valkey is a significant event in the open-source community. This fork of Redis is backed by some of the biggest names in the tech industry and is designed to keep the old group of maintainers together. While the original Redis license change was a contentious issue, AWS and other cloud service providers have quickly rallied behind Valkey. This fork is expected to be a major player in the in-memory data store market.
meta_desc: "Valkey: Revolutionizing In-memory Data Storage with the Support of AWS, Google Cloud, and More! Join the Valkey community today and be a part of the future of open-source data storage."

post_title: Iron Sheepdog is fixing short-haul trucking from the bottom up
title: "Simplifying Short-Haul Trucking: Iron Sheepdog's Focus on User Adoption"
post_content:
Iron Sheepdog, the company founded by Larry Lawrence, Williamsburg, Virginia-based co-founder and CTO, is focused on simplifying and streamlining the short-haul trucking industry. This software solution aims to make transportation logistics more transparent, efficient, and cost-effective for both companies and truckers. Iron Sheepdog announced a $10 million Series B round led by SJF Ventures, and the company's CEO, Mike Van Sickel, stated that they are looking to scale while maintaining the trust of their users.

Iron Sheepdog’s software enables companies to track their contracted trucks, providing real-time information on their location, job duration, and cost. The company also offers an easy-to-use app for truckers to accept jobs, get paid, and monitor their workload. By providing a user-friendly interface, Iron Sheepdog has been able to achieve high adoption rates and profitability.

The company's unique approach to building software for short-haul trucking has set it apart from competitors. Iron Sheepdog started by focusing on the needs of the subhaulers, the short-haul truck drivers, rather than the contractors. Lawrence explained that they chose to look at the problem from the bottom up, creating a simple app that would appeal to the truckers. By making the app free and providing 24-hour pay, Iron Sheepdog was able to attract more subhaulers, which in turn attracted more contractors and brokers.

Iron Sheepdog's focus on adoption sets it apart from other tech companies. Van Sickel emphasized the importance of building solutions that are easy to use and embrace by the individuals they target. Iron Sheepdog's success has been built on a "crawl, walk, run" approach, prioritizing adoption and building trust with their users.

Iron Sheepdog's software solution is poised to revolutionize the short-haul trucking industry. By simplifying the process of managing and coordinating short-haul transportation, Iron Sheepdog is helping companies reduce costs, increase efficiency, and improve communication between subhaulers, contractors, and brokers.

In conclusion, Iron Sheepdog's focus on user adoption and ease of use has set it apart from competitors and positioned it for success in the short-haul trucking industry. As the company continues to grow and scale, it will be crucial to maintain the trust of its users while expanding its reach to new customers. Iron Sheepdog's software solution is an essential tool for companies looking to improve their transportation logistics and compete in the fast-paced short-haul trucking market.
meta_desc: Iron Sheepdog's simplified software streamlines short-haul trucking, leading to cost savings, efficiency improvements, and increased trust. With $10 million in funding, Iron Sheepdog looks to scale while staying true to its user-centered approach. Try Iron Sheepdog's app today and experience the benefits of efficient transportation logistics management.

post_title: A new strategy for fabricating high-density vertical organic electrochemical transistor arrays
title: "High-density OECTs with excellent performance: A new e-beam exposure strategy from Northwestern University"
post_content:
Organic Electrochemical Transistors (OECTs): A Promising Class of Transistors for Neuromorphic Systems

Organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs) are a new class of transistors that have shown great potential in modulating electrical current in response to small changes in voltage applied to their gate electrode. These transistors could revolutionize the development of various brain-inspired and wearable technologies. However, most conventional OECTs developed so far have been found to exhibit various limitations, including limited stability and slow redox processes, which can significantly impair their performance.

A recent study by researchers at Northwestern University has proposed a new strategy to fabricate high-density and mechanically flexible OECTs. Their approach, outlined in a paper published in Nature Electronics, was used to create various electronic components based on OECT arrays and circuits.

The researchers successfully fabricated p- and n-channel vertical OECT active-matrix arrays using a novel e-beam exposure process. This technique allowed them to produce a pattern on the semiconducting films without employing masks or chemical solvents that could damage the materials. This made the films electronically inactive (i.e., insulating) without affecting their ability to conduct ions.

The resulting p- and n-type vertical OECT active-matrix arrays exhibited transconductances of 0.08-1.7 S, transient times of less than 100 µs, and stable switching properties of more than 100,000 cycles. Additionally, the researchers successfully used their fabrication strategy to create vertically stacked logic circuits based on their OECTs, including NOT, NAND, and NOR gates. These circuits performed remarkably well while maintaining excellent operational stability.

The study's findings highlight the potential of OECTs in developing biosensors, wearable devices, and neuromorphic systems. However, the researchers noted that restrictions in the micro- and nanopatterning of organic semiconductors, as well as topological irregularities, often limit their use in monolithically integrated circuits.

In conclusion, the new e-beam exposure strategy developed by the Northwestern University researchers promises to significantly boost the stability and performance of OECT circuits. The study's findings pave the way for the scalable fabrication of OECTs, contributing to their integration into electronic devices.

Reference: Kim, J., Pankow, R. M., & et al. (2024). Monolithically integrated high-density vertical organic electrochemical transistor arrays and complementary circuits. Nature Electronics. DOI: 10.1038/s41928-024-01127-x
meta_desc: Discover the potential of Organic Electrochemical Transistors (OECTs) in revolutionizing neuromorphic systems and wearable technology. Read our latest study to learn about Northwestern University's new strategy for fabricating high-density and mechanically flexible OECTs.
focuskeywords: The keyphrase for the article is "Organic Electrochemical Transistors" (OECT).

post_title: Women in AI: Kate Devlin of King's College is researching AI and intimacy
title: Kate Devlin: Advocating for Socially Beneficial Robotics and AI Systems
post_content:
Title: Kate Devlin: Advocating for Socially Beneficial Robotics and AI Systems

Kate Devlin is a lecturer in AI and society at King's College London and the author of "Turned On: Science, Sex and Robots." Her research explores how people interact with and react to technologies, both past and future. Aside from her academic work, Kate is also a board member of the Open Rights Group, which works to preserve digital rights and freedoms.

In an exclusive interview, Kate talks about her journey in the AI field, her proudest achievements, and her advice for women seeking to enter the field. She also discusses the challenges facing AI as it evolves and the importance of responsible AI.

How did you get your start in AI? What attracted you to the field?

Kate started off as an archaeologist, eventually moving across disciplines and completing a Ph.D. in computer science in 2004. She was drawn to AI because it enabled her to integrate her love of technology and her fascination with human behavior. Kate ended up focusing on human-computer interaction and the reception that technological innovations have from people.

What work are you most proud of (in the AI field)?

Kate is pleased that intimacy and AI is now taken seriously as an academic area of study. There has been some amazing research on this topic, and she is particularly proud of the work that explores the ethical and social implications of technology and intimacy. Kate feels that her research has helped to shift the perception of intimacy and AI from a highly unlikely and niche area of study to one that is now recognized as having significant meaning for individuals.

How do you navigate the challenges of the male-dominated tech industry, and, by extension, the male-dominated AI industry?

Kate believes that women in tech and AI should persevere and not let gender discrimination discourage them. She acknowledges that the tech industry is still sexist, but she is optimistic that change will occur at a more rapid pace as more women become visible in visible, top positions. Kate also believes that it is essential to tackle sexism in schools and beyond, and to create a more flexible work environment that allows women to balance work and family responsibilities more effectively.

What advice would you give to women seeking to enter the AI field?

Kate's advice to women
meta_desc: seeking to enter the AI field is to focus on the areas of AI that interest them and that they have a natural aptitude for. She suggests looking at the intersections between technology and human behavior, as well as the ethical and social implications of AI. Kate also advises women to seek out mentorship and networking opportunities to gain insight into the field and to be more visible within it. Finally, she emphasizes the importance of advocating for socially beneficial robotics and AI systems, and working to ensure that technology is designed with people's needs in mind.
focuskeywords: seeking to enter the AI field is to focus on the areas of AI that interest them and that they have a natural aptitude for. She suggests looking at the intersections between technology and human behavior, as well as the ethical and social implications of AI. Kate also advises women to seek out mentorship and networking opportunities to gain insight into the field and to be more visible within it. Finally, she emphasizes the importance of advocating for socially beneficial robotics and AI systems, and working to ensure that technology is designed with people's needs in mind.

post_title: Robinhood's new Gold Card, BaaS challenges and the tiny startup that caught Stripe's eye
title: Fintech Insights: Robinhood's New Gold Card, BaaS Challenges & Stripe's Latest Investment
post_content:
Welcome to TechCrunch! This week, we're excited to share with you the latest news and insights in the fintech industry. From Robinhood's new Gold Card to the challenges facing the BaaS space and the latest investments in fintech startups, we've got you covered.

Main story:
Robinhood's new Gold Card is sure to make waves in the fintech industry. With its impressive features, such as 3% cash back and the ability to invest that cash back via the company's brokerage account, the Gold Card is set to impact Robinhood's bottom line and potentially offer a lucrative new offering. Robinhood incorporated the technology it acquired when buying startup X1 last summer for $95 million and turned it into a potentially very lucrative new product.

Analysis:
The BaaS space is facing challenges, with VC-backed BaaS companies like Synctera and Treasury Prime resorting to layoffs to preserve cash over the past year. The FDIC also announced consent orders against Sutton Bank and Piermont Bank, telling them to keep a closer eye on their fintechs' compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act and money laundering rules.

Dollars and cents:
PayPal Ventures has invested in Qoala, an Indonesian startup that provides personal insurance products covering a variety of risks. MassMutual Ventures also participated in Qoala's new $47 million round of funding. New Retirement, a Mill Valley-based company building software to help people create financial retirement plans, has raised $20 million in a tranche of funding. Zaver, a Swedish B2C buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) provider in Europe, has closed a $10 million extension to its Series A funding round.

What else we're writing:
We recently explored how a tiny four-person startup, Supaglue, caught Stripe's eye. Supaglue, previously known as Supergrain, is an open source developer platform for user-facing integrations. The team is now going to help Stripe on real-time analytics and reporting across its platform and third-party apps for its Revenue and Finance Automation suite.

Additionally, we have some exciting news about the future of fintech. Maju Kuruvilla, the former Amazon executive who

post_title: Fisker enters into dumpster fire territory and Tesla chases FSD revenue
title: "Fisker bankruptcy, EV market trends & insights from little birds - TechCrunch Mobility"
post_content:
Welcome back to TechCrunch Mobility, your go-to source for news and insights on the future of transportation. Last week, we reported on the challenges faced by Fisker, an electric vehicle startup that had to temporarily halt production and filed for bankruptcy. Our analysis of the situation delved into the root causes of Fisker's problems, including a loss of track on customer payments and an internal audit that took months to complete.

In addition to Fisker's struggles, other topics covered in the latest edition of TechCrunch Mobility include the sale of Arrival's assets to Canoo, a struggling electric vehicle startup, and the profile of Ionobell, a startup working to increase EV range through recycled silicon battery materials. We also highlighted a $1 billion boost for Lucid, an EV startup backed by Saudi Arabia.

Our newsletter also included a section featuring "little birds" who shared their insights on the transportation industry. We encourage our readers to share their own stories and perspectives by reaching out to us via email or SecureDrop.

If you're interested in receiving TechCrunch Mobility every week, sign up for our newsletter by clicking the link "TechCrunch Mobility" in the header.

We hope you enjoyed this edition of TechCrunch Mobility. Stay tuned for more in-depth analysis and insights on the future of transportation.

post_title: Microsoft to unbundle Office and Teams globally following years-long criticism
title: Microsoft Unbundles Office and Teams Globally amid Criticism
post_content:
Microsoft is set to release a new version of its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription service that excludes Teams, following a review by the European Union regulator and complaints from rival Slack. The move comes after Microsoft agreed to sell Office 365 without Microsoft Teams in the EU and Switzerland in 2020.

Microsoft introduced Teams as a complementary service to the Office 365 suite in 2017, but some businesses argued that the company had an unfair advantage by bundling the two offerings. Slack, which is owned by Salesforce, called the move "illegal," claiming that Microsoft forced installation of Teams on customers through the market-dominant productivity suite and concealed the true cost of the chat and video service.

In a statement to Reuters, Microsoft said that the unbundling "also addresses feedback from the European Commission by providing multinational companies more flexibility when they want to standardize their purchasing across geographies."

Reuters reported that Microsoft will introduce the new Office 365 lineups on Monday, but Microsoft had not yet implemented the change at the time of publication. TechCrunch has reached out to Microsoft for more information, and we will provide updates as we receive them.

The new version of Office 365 will provide businesses with more flexibility and control over their purchases, while still retaining the core Office 365 suite of tools. This move is likely to be seen as a positive step by many businesses, as it will give them more control over their productivity and collaboration tools.
meta_desc: Want to learn more about Microsoft's latest move to unbundle Office and Teams? Read our article now to find out what's happening and why. Get the latest news and updates on Microsoft's new Office 365 lineups that exclude Teams. Don't miss out!

post_title: Fisker loses customers' money, Robinhood launches a credit card, and Google generates travel itineraries
title: Fisker Suspended, AI-Powered Itineraries, and Robinhood's New Card: This Week's Tech News
post_content:
This week, TechCrunch's WiR brings you the latest happenings in the tech world, including Fisker's temporary loss of millions of dollars in customer payments, Facebook's secret project to intercept and decrypt Snapchat traffic, and the resignation of Stability AI's founder. Keep reading to learn more.
News
Fisker Suspended: Fisker's stock trading was halted on the New York Stock Exchange after the company's abnormally low stock levels were discovered.
AI-Powered Itineraries: Google has added a new feature to its Search Generative Experience that allows users to ask Search to plan a travel itinerary using AI.
Robinhood's New Card: Robinhood has launched its new Gold Card, powered by X1's technology, with a list of features that could make Apple Card users jealous.
AT&T Data Breach: The personal information of some 73 million AT&T customers was spilled online this week. However, AT&T remains mum on the details of the hack.
Funding
Copilot Raises $6 Million: Copilot, the budgeting app, has raised $6 million in a Series A round led by Nico Wittenborn's Adjacent.
Liquid Death's Fundraise: Canned water startup Liquid Death raised $67 million, bringing its total funding to more than $267 million.
PipeDreams Venture: Dan Laufer, a former Nextdoor executive, has raised $25 million from Canvas Ventures and others for PipeDreams, a startup that acquires and scales mom-and-pop HVAC and plumbing companies.
Analysis
Nvidia and AWS Parallels: Ron discusses the similarities between Nvidia's and AWS's growth trajectories.
Podcasts
Equity Podcast: The crew at Equity discussed Robinhood's new credit card, Fisker's latest woes, and Databricks' new AI model.
Found Podcast: Allison Wolff, the CEO of Vibrant Planet, discussed how proper land management can help prevent and control wildfires.
